description: Discover the renewal of nature, spring traditions, and seasonal changes

questions.question: What causes spring fever?
questions.funFact: Increased sunlight exposure in spring can reduce melatonin production by 50%!
questions.story: Spring fever isn't an illness but a set of physical and psychological changes. As days get longer, the body produces less melatonin (sleep hormone) and more serotonin (mood-lifting hormone). These hormonal changes can lead to increased energy, improved mood, and changes in appetite.

questions.question: Which spring flower typically blooms first?
questions.funFact: These flowers can bloom even through snow, thanks to a natural antifreeze in their cells!
questions.story: Snowdrops (Galanthus) have earned the nickname 'February fairmaids' because they often emerge while winter still holds its grip. These hardy flowers contain a special protein that prevents ice crystals from forming in their cells, allowing them to survive and bloom in near-freezing temperatures.

questions.question: What is the March equinox also known as?
questions.funFact: The first word comes from the Latin word for spring!
questions.story: The vernal equinox marks the astronomical beginning of spring in the Northern Hemisphere. Ancient cultures celebrated this day as a time of renewal and rebirth. The Great Pyramid of Giza was built to align with the sun on the spring equinox.

questions.question: Which spring flower blooms underwater?
questions.funFact: These plants create their own air bubbles!
questions.story: The water violet, despite its name, is not related to true violets. It grows completely submerged until flowering time, when it creates special floating leaves to support its delicate purple blooms. Medieval herbalists believed it had magical properties.

questions.question: Which spring tradition involves cheese rolling?
questions.funFact: The event has been happening for over 200 years!
questions.story: The Cooper's Hill Cheese Rolling in Gloucestershire, England, involves participants chasing a 9-pound wheel of Double Gloucester cheese down a steep hill. The dangerous tradition has resulted in numerous injuries but continues to attract participants worldwide.

questions.question: Which spring animal never drinks water?
questions.funFact: These creatures can survive in extreme temperatures!
questions.story: The kangaroo rat, active in spring after winter rains produce seeds, never drinks water. It gets all its moisture from metabolizing dry seeds. Its specialized kidneys are so efficient that its urine is five times more concentrated than human urine.

questions.question: Which spring festival releases butterflies?
questions.funFact: This celebration marks a celestial alignment!
questions.story: During Japan's Higan festival, which occurs during the spring equinox, butterflies are released to symbolize the souls of ancestors. The week-long Buddhist observance includes visits to family graves and special memorial services.

questions.question: Which spring plant grows in the dark?
questions.funFact: This plant takes years to reach maturity!
questions.story: True wasabi grows naturally in mountain stream beds under the forest canopy. Japanese farmers recreate these conditions by growing it in flooded mountain fields under black cloth covers. The plant requires extremely specific conditions to thrive.

questions.question: Which spring bird builds nests of saliva?
questions.funFact: These nests are considered a rare delicacy!
questions.story: The edible-nest swiftlet builds its nest entirely from its own solidified saliva. These birds make their nests in caves during spring breeding season. The nests have been harvested for over 400 years for use in Chinese cuisine.

questions.question: Which spring parade features giant dolls?
questions.story: Las Fallas in Valencia, Spain, features huge satirical figures called 'ninots' made of wood, cardboard, and papier-mâché. These elaborate sculptures, some reaching several stories high, are displayed for a week before being burned in a spectacular finale.

questions.question: Which spring vegetable grows in the sea?
questions.funFact: This plant was used by ancient mariners!
questions.story: Rock samphire grows on sea cliffs and rocky shores. In Tudor times, professional samphire gatherers would scale dangerous cliffs to harvest it. Shakespeare mentioned this perilous profession in King Lear, calling it a 'dreadful trade.'

questions.question: Which spring activity involves maple trees?
questions.funFact: The process requires specific temperature conditions!
questions.story: Maple sugaring occurs when spring temperatures fluctuate between freezing at night and above freezing during the day. Native Americans taught early colonists this process, which requires collecting and boiling down 40 gallons of sap to make one gallon of syrup.

questions.question: Which spring flower changes color?
questions.funFact: The plant's name means 'water vessel' in Greek!
questions.story: Hydrangeas can change color based on the soil's pH level. This discovery was made by Victorian gardeners who noticed their plants changing color when wood ash or rusty nails were added to the soil. The phenomenon led to extensive horticultural research.

questions.question: Which spring glows brightest?
questions.story: Yellowstone's Grand Prismatic Spring reaches its most vibrant colors in spring when increasing sunlight promotes bacterial growth, creating stunning rings of orange, yellow, and blue.

questions.question: Which spring flower grows fastest?
questions.story: Chinese Moso bamboo can grow up to 91 cm (35.8 inches) in a single day during spring, making it the world's fastest-growing plant.

questions.question: Which spring bird flies highest?
questions.funFact: They cross the world's highest mountains!
questions.story: Bar-headed Geese migrate over Mount Everest in spring, flying at altitudes up to 29,000 feet, making them the world's highest-flying birds.

questions.question: Which spring tree blooms longest?
questions.funFact: The vines can live for centuries!
questions.story: Japan's Ashikaga Flower Park features a 150-year-old wisteria that blooms for several weeks in spring, covering half an acre with cascading purple flowers.

questions.question: Which spring river flows pink?
questions.story: Sweden's Torne River turns pink during spring thaw due to unique algae that thrive in the melting ice, creating a spectacular natural display.
